ripe 0.1.0
  • Reference
  • Articles
  • Get started

ripe

The goal of ripe is to create a more flexible way to rerun {magrittr} pipes.

Installation

remotes::install_github('yonicd/ripe')

Goal

We want to write the following in a shorter and more flexible way


f <- function(){
  
  stats::runif(20)%>%
    sample(10)%>%
    utils::head(5)
}

replicate(n=3,f(),simplify = FALSE)
#> [[1]]
#> [1] 0.8002557 0.4751122 0.2201699 0.9217119 0.8843756
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> [1] 0.9231412 0.2913262 0.1899650 0.3964992 0.6789112
#> 
#> [[3]]
#> [1] 0.5743133 0.8919166 0.1333068 0.9736342 0.7949436

This is better!

stats::runif(20)%>%
  sample(10)%>%
  utils::head(5)%>%
  ripe(replicate,n=4,simplify=FALSE)
#> [[1]]
#> [1] 0.13442758 0.05091904 0.54674572 0.84051403 0.24511144
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> [1] 0.7593286 0.5736068 0.5598740 0.1901749 0.9960589
#> 
#> [[3]]
#> [1] 0.60066821 0.38276844 0.80535838 0.04362504 0.14055155
#> 
#> [[4]]
#> [1] 0.5235122 0.4969701 0.7102464 0.6979855 0.2676185

Manipulate Chain Replicates

We can now manipulate the chain or move ripe around into different subsets of the chain, creating iterative replication workflows.


stats::runif(20)%>%
  #sample(10)%>%
  utils::head(5)%>%
  ripe(replicate,n=4,simplify=FALSE)
#> [[1]]
#> [1] 0.07197262 0.49673030 0.51796618 0.90701614 0.25529426
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> [1] 0.04013945 0.03520064 0.78725533 0.71588967 0.31502794
#> 
#> [[3]]
#> [1] 0.8086515 0.6695524 0.9948631 0.1883586 0.5645010
#> 
#> [[4]]
#> [1] 0.6624472 0.1263084 0.1482204 0.3609371 0.9590423

Convert Chain to Lazy

You can also quickly convert the chain to a lazyeval function

f <- stats::runif(20)%>%
  sample(10)%>%
  utils::head(5)%>%
  lazy()

f()
#> [1] 0.8627660 0.2968800 0.1694841 0.7943510 0.7635527
f()
#> [1] 0.86146605 0.72485326 0.58737354 0.55864671 0.01810526
